node.title: The end of an era
node.description: The End of an Era. The last day of music at the old Met. Walter Slezak, son of tenor Leo Slezak, joins Milton Cross and Miles Kastendieck to give an account of the farewell concert, April 16, 1966.

node.title: A long look back, part 2
node.description: This program presents the conclusion to the reminiscences by Licia Albanese and Giovanni Martinelli.

node.title: A long look back, part 1
node.description: A Long Look Back. First of two programs in which Giovanni Martinelli and Licia Albanese review much of the old Met's history. They recall their wonderful experiences in the old house.

node.title: 1963 through 1964
node.description: 1963 -1964. Dame Alicia Markova is interviewed; she came to the Met to direct the ballet.

node.title: 1959 through 1960
node.description: 1959 -1960. Birgit Nilsson makes her debut and is interviewed.
1950. Hans Hotter, German basso, relates some of the experiences of his rather brief Metropolitan career.

node.title: 1950 through 1951
node.description: 1950 -1951. Rudolf Bing assumes general manager at the Met. Cesare Siepi recalls his debut in Mr. Bing's first opening night.

node.title: 1948 through 1949
node.description: 1948 -1949. Contralto Jean Madeira makes her debut. She is interviewed about her career.
1945. Robert Merrill describes his career.
1940. Eleanor Steber, soprano, is interviewed.

node.title: 1941 through 1945
node.description: 1941 -1945. The war years and their effect on the Met. Dorothy Kirsten is interviewed about behind-the-scenes complications which take place during every opera season.
1940. Russian basso Alexander Kipnis recalls his years at the old Metropolitan. He recalls how he discovered Kirsten Flagstad.

node.title: 1939 through 1940
node.description: 1939 -1940. Helen Traubel, soprano, is interviewed about her career. She recalls the incident with Rudolf Bing that caused her to terminate her career.

node.title: 1938 through 1939
node.description: 1938 -1939. Rise Stevens' first appearance. In an interview she recalls her long career.

node.title: 1937 through 1938
node.description: 1937 -1938. Erich Leinsdorf arrives to assist Artur Bodanzky with the German operas. Maestro Leinsdorf is interviewed.

node.title: 1934 through 1937
node.description: 1934 -1937. Transition to Edward Johnson's managerial regime. Lucrezia Bori gives her farewell speech at her last performance. Kerstin Thorberg is interviewed.

node.title: 1934 through 1935
node.description: 1934 -1935. Helen Jepson, soprana, makes her debut. She is interviewed.

node.title: 1933 through 1935
node.description: 1933 -1935. Lotte Lehmann makes her long-awaited debut. She is interviewed about her career and describes her association with Lauritz Melchior, Maria Olszewaka, Richard Strauss, and Bruno Walter.

node.title: 1932 through 1933
node.description: 1932 -1933. The Metropolitan Opera Association is formed. Soprana Frida Leider talks about her career in New York.

node.title: 1926 through 1932
node.description: 1926 -1932. The Depression brings almost complete financial disaster. Otto Kahn resigns from the Met's Board of Directors. Voices of Ezio Pinza, Grace Moore, Gladys Swarthout, Lily Pons are featured.

node.title: 1925 through 1926
node.description: 1925 -1926. Conclusion of Melchior interview. Refer to previous entry for information.

node.title: 1925 through 1926
node.description: 1925 -1926. Lauritz Melchior, Heldentenor, is interviewed. First of two parts.

node.title: 1923 through 1924
node.description: 1923 -1924. Karin Branzell, contralto, recalls her 20 year career at the Met.

node.title: 1920 through 1921
node.description: 1920 -1921. Tragedy strikes during a performance of Elisir d'Amore in Brooklyn and signals the end of Caruso's career. Rosa Ponselle, Giuseppe Bamboschek and Bruno Zirato recall his death.

node.title: 1921 through 1924
node.description: 1921 -1924. Filling the void left by Caruso's death. Geraldine Farrer leaves the Met. Wagner stages a comeback.
1918. This program presents the conclusion to the Rosa Ponselle interview.
1918. Rosa Ponselle, the soprano, makes a sensational debut. In the first of a two-part interview she tells of her first seasons with the company.

node.title: 1913 through 1918
node.description: 1913 -1918. The great ticket scandal. The Toscanini furor. German opera is dismissed at outbreak of war. Voices of Giovanni Martinelli, Giuseppe De Luca, Claudia Muzio, Florence Easton.
1913. Giuseppe Bamboschek arrives in New York to serve as company's musical secretary. In an interview he describes the difficult situations he encountered during the Gatti era.

node.title: 1909 through 1913
node.description: 1909 -1913. Hammerstein, a competitor, is forced to sell out, leaving the Met supreme in New York. Puccini attends premiere of Fanciulla del West.  Recordings by Bori, Margarete Matzenauer, Luisa Tetrazzini.
1909. Leo Slezak, the outstanding tenor, arrives. His son Walter is interviewed about his life with "Pappa" at the old Met.

node.title: 1907 through 1909
node.description: 1907 -1909. Beginning of Gatti's reign. Toscanini arrives. New talent: Emmy Destinn, Maria Gay, Frances Alda, Pasquale Amato, Adamo Didur.

node.title: 1903 through 1907
node.description: 1903 -1907. The Conried Regime. The controversial Parsifal premiere and the scandalous Salome first night. Early influence of J.P. Morgan. Features Geraldine Farrar, Olive Fremstad, Otto Goritz.
1903. Features Enrico Caruso, with reminiscences by Bruno Zirato, Rosa Ponselle, Giuseppe Bamboschek.

1907. Feodor Chaliapin, the Russian basso, makes his debut and immediately causes great controversy. His daughter, Tania Chaliapin, is interviewed about the difficulty her father had in adjusting to the United States.

node.title: 1898 through 1903
node.description: 1898 -1903. Features Maurice Grau, Lilli Lehmann, Johanna Gadski, Ernestine Schumann-Heink, Antonio Scotti, Anton Van Rooy.

node.title: 1893 through 1897
node.description: 1893 -1897. The House re-opens following a fire. Features recordings of Emma Calve', Pol Plancon, Nellie Melba, Francesco Tamagno.

node.title: 1884 through 1892
node.description: 1884 -1892: The Wagnerian Tide. Features the voices of Lilli Lehmann, Lillian Nordica, Edouard de Reszke.

node.title: 1883: A new opera house is decreed
node.description: 1883: A new opera house is decreed.
